turn.speaker: alan_h_levine
turn.label: Mr. Alan H. Levine
turn.text: No, I don't.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are you saying that federal courts are better qualified to answer that question that school boards?

turn.speaker: alan_h_levine
turn.label: Mr. Alan H. Levine
turn.text: I do not whatsoever.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I would like to think we are, but I know we aren't.

turn.speaker: alan_h_levine
turn.label: Mr. Alan H. Levine
turn.text: No, and I don't think the federal courts are better suited to do that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what do we do then?

turn.speaker: alan_h_levine
turn.label: Mr. Alan H. Levine
turn.text: What has happened... First of all we take issue with the district judge's conclusion.
We did not concede that in summary judgment.
That is his reading of the record, and he draws those inferences, though Judge Newman was not at all willing to abide by those inferences.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, at least we have two judges one way and two the other, don't we?

turn.speaker: alan_h_levine
turn.label: Mr. Alan H. Levine
turn.text: Well, we do have that, but there is simply no disputing what they say here about Cleaver and about Malcolm X and about George Washington being a slaveholder.
That is all in the record.
That is not about vulgarity.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But somebody has to make a decision as to what is educationally suitable.

turn.speaker: alan_h_levine
turn.label: Mr. Alan H. Levine
turn.text: I don't think that a school board can cloak its political concerns in the mantle of educational suitability.
They may say that, and they may want the Court to believe that is what went on here, but they did in fact make some very explicit political judgments.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, on Page A-107, the court made an even narrower... drew an even narrower inference from the facts.
"The board has restricted access only to certain books which the board believed to be, in essence, vulgar. "
That was his assessment of what the board did.
That is Judge Pratt's assessment.
That's correct.
I... Like Judge--
--I know you disagree with that.

turn.speaker: alan_h_levine
turn.label: Mr. Alan H. Levine
turn.text: Well, the reason, Your Honor, is, there isn't a claim that there is a single vulgar word in all of A Reader for Writers.
There is nothing said about A Reader for Writers that suggests vulgarity.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Of course, you say all of these books should go back on the shelves.

turn.speaker: alan_h_levine
turn.label: Mr. Alan H. Levine
turn.text: That's correct.
Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, counsel.
Do you have anything further, Mr. Lipp?

section.heading: Rebuttal of George W. Lipp, Jr.

turn.speaker: george_w_lipp_jr
turn.label: Mr. George W. Lipp, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I do, very briefly, Mr. Chief Justice.
I would like to lay to rest the allegations of political motivation.
I would like to do it by stating that I have read all of the books involved very recently.
I have read the one book that is allegedly to have referred to Malcolm X.
That was a different edition.
The board banned a book that had absolutely no reference to Malcolm X.
That was the book that contained A Modest Proposal.
With regard to A Hero Ain't Nothing But A Sandwich, not--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: On that book, Mr.... that book, did you refer... that one was not vulgar.
Is that correct?

turn.speaker: george_w_lipp_jr
turn.label: Mr. George W. Lipp, Jr.
turn.text: --That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There is no vulgarity at all in that book?

turn.speaker: george_w_lipp_jr
turn.label: Mr. George W. Lipp, Jr.
turn.text: Their feeling is that it was--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So the banning of that book cannot be justified on vulgarity grounds.

turn.speaker: george_w_lipp_jr
turn.label: Mr. George W. Lipp, Jr.
turn.text: --That is correct.
They felt it was in bad taste.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, what is the ground for banning it?
Just bad taste?

turn.speaker: george_w_lipp_jr
turn.label: Mr. George W. Lipp, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, supposing they took... would it be permissible for them to take every book out of the library they thought was in bad taste?
What does bad taste mean?

turn.speaker: george_w_lipp_jr
turn.label: Mr. George W. Lipp, Jr.
turn.text: If they felt that that bad taste was related to educational suitability, I would think they would have that right, as long as they are not--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Could they take every book out of the library that contained the word "ain't"?
0 [Generallaughter.]

turn.speaker: george_w_lipp_jr
turn.label: Mr. George W. Lipp, Jr.
turn.text: --They would be very foolish, and if that were the sole... if that were the sole--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the judge here says they were foolish.

turn.speaker: george_w_lipp_jr
turn.label: Mr. George W. Lipp, Jr.
turn.text: --If that were the sole reason--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is the sole reason.
They don't want the children to form the bad habit of using the word "ain't".
I was taught that was a vulgar word.
0 [Generallaughter.]

turn.speaker: george_w_lipp_jr
turn.label: Mr. George W. Lipp, Jr.
turn.text: --If that were the sole reason, Mr. Justice Stevens, I... I still question whether that would--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I really want... this is a serious question.
I am not playing games.

turn.speaker: george_w_lipp_jr
turn.label: Mr. George W. Lipp, Jr.
turn.text: --I realize that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would that be a sufficient reason to be a total answer to a constitutional objection?

turn.speaker: george_w_lipp_jr
turn.label: Mr. George W. Lipp, Jr.
turn.text: I think it would, because it does not address a doctrine of thought, an ideology or favor a political party or religion, and so forth.
I want also to add that not only did the other book, A Hero Ain't Nothing But A Sandwich, refer to George Washington in what the board felt was disparaging terms, it was laced with obscenities.
The political excerpts that Mr. Levine has said--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What if they barred the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution, which also recognize slavery?

turn.speaker: george_w_lipp_jr
turn.label: Mr. George W. Lipp, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, the political motivation that Mr. Levine is saying "they" had was motivation of the Randolph New York State School District that had a list of excerpts with these comments, their own comments, sitting on a table at this conference that the board went to at the request of a regent of the state of New York.

I want to remind the Court that there are substantial limitations upon the requirement for content neutrality, among which are the Young against American Mini-Theaters case, where Mr. Justice Stevens wrote the majority decision.
We have, of course, the fact that juveniles do not have rights equal with adults.
You have many, many areas where there are erosions upon this so-called absolute right that it appears that Mr. Levine is claiming.
It is not absolute, especially in the area of public education.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
